content.sentence:
What does a mechanical foreman do?

A mechanical foreman supervises technicians and checks repair work on machines.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He plans daily tasks and assigns jobs to fitters and welders.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He inspects engines, pumps, and compressors for unusual sounds.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He doesn’t lock out the power supply before maintenance.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He uses measuring tools such as micrometers and vernier callipers.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He does not ignore oil leaks or overheating problems in machines.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He orders spare parts and ensures the workshop has enough tools.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He checks alignment and adjusts belts, pulleys, and bearings.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He does not record the completed jobs or report faults to the manager.

What does a mechanical foreman do?

He monitors safety practices and trains workers on proper handling of equipment.

content.intro: The PowerPress 800 Hydraulic Press Machine is used in mechanical workshops for shaping, bending, pressing bearings, and assembling parts under high pressure.

subsections.subtitle: Main Components
items: Hydraulic Cylinder – applies pressure to compress or shape materials.
Ram (Piston Rod) – moves downward to apply force to the workpiece.
Worktable (Bed Plate) – supports the material being pressed.
Pump Handle / Motor Switch – activates the hydraulic system (manual or electric).
Pressure Gauge – displays the applied force in tons or bar.
Safety Guard – protects the operator from accidental contact.
Oil Reservoir – stores hydraulic oil for smooth operation.
Release Valve – controls the pressure release after each operation.

steps: Place the machine on a level floor and ensure it is stable.
Fill the oil reservoir with the recommended hydraulic oil (ISO VG 46).
Connect to power for the motorised version or secure the manual pump handle.
Adjust the worktable height using the locking pins according to material size.
Place the workpiece at the centre of the bed plate.
Close the release valve to build pressure.
Activate the pump handle or motor switch to lower the ram.
Monitor the pressure gauge carefully during operation.
Once the operation is complete, open the release valve slowly to raise the ram.
Turn off the motor or secure the handle before removing the workpiece.

subsections.subtitle: Common Issues and Solutions
items: Low Pressure: Check oil level; refill or bleed air from the system.
Oil Leaks: Inspect seals, hoses, and connections for damage or leaks.
No Ram Movement: Ensure the release valve is fully closed.
Abnormal Noise: Air trapped in the system — bleed and refill oil.
Inaccurate Pressure Reading: Calibrate or replace the pressure gauge.

subsections.subtitle: Maintenance Tips
items: Check oil level weekly.
Replace hydraulic oil every six months.
Keep the ram and bed plate clean and lightly oiled.
Never exceed the rated capacity (80 tons).
Ensure all guards are in place before operating.
Operate only after receiving proper training.
Never place hands or tools under the ram while it is in motion.
Do not exceed the maximum pressure capacity.
Keep the floor area dry to avoid slips.
Turn off the main power before performing maintenance.
Always wear safety shoes, gloves, and eye protection.
